인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Hello, the weather is nice today.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: The most common Korean greeting, used any time of day. Literally means 'are you at peace?'

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: You're leaving already? Goodbye!
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Said to the person who is leaving. Literally means 'go in peace.'

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: I'll go first. Goodbye!
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Said to the person who is staying behind. Literally means 'stay in peace.'

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Thank you for helping me.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Formal thank you suitable for strangers, elders, and professional settings. More polite than 고마워요.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Thanks for the gift! I really like it.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Casual but still polite thanks. Use with friends or people your age. For very casual speech: 고마워.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: I'm sorry for being late.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Formal apology for serious situations or when speaking to elders/superiors.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Oh, sorry! I didn't see you.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Casual but polite apology. Good for minor everyday situations with peers.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Don't worry, it's okay.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Very versatile word. Can mean 'it's okay,' 'I'm fine,' 'no thanks,' or 'don't worry about it.'

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Yes, that's right. I think so too.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Also used as a filler word to show you're listening, like 'uh-huh.' Pronounced more like 'ne' or 'de.'

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: No, I'm not a student.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Polite form of 'no.' The casual form is 아니 or 아니야.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Just a moment, I'll be right there!
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Literally 'just a brief moment.' Very useful when you need someone to wait.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Excuse me, where is the restroom?
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Very polite way to get someone's attention or to excuse yourself. More formal than 저기요.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: What did you say? I couldn't hear well.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Polite way to ask someone to repeat themselves. Can sound surprised if said with strong intonation.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Yes, I understand. I'll do that.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Shows you understood something. 알겠습니다 is the formal version often used at work.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: I don't know the meaning of this word.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Softer than 몰라요. The -겠- adds a nuance of 'I'm not sure' rather than flat 'I don't know.'

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: How do you do. Nice to meet you.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Standard greeting when meeting someone for the first time. Often paired with a slight bow.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Today was fun. See you again!
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Friendly and casual way to say goodbye, implying you'll meet again.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).english: how are you? / are you doing well?
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: It's been a while! How are you?
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Used when you haven't seen someone in a while. Not used as a daily greeting like English 'how are you.'

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Good morning! Did you sleep well?
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Less common than in English. Koreans often just say 안녕하세요 in the morning.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: It's late. Good night.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Honorific form, used toward elders or parents. 주무시다 is the honorific of 자다 (to sleep).

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).english: good work / thanks for your effort
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Good work today. Get some good rest.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Very common in Korean workplaces and daily life. Said when someone finishes work or a task.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: You're welcome, it's nothing.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Literally means 'ten million.' In practice, 아니에요 (no, it's nothing) is more commonly used.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Excuse me, how much is this?
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Used to call a waiter, shop clerk, or stranger. Literally means 'over there.' Very useful in restaurants.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Hello? Can you talk right now?
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Only used when answering or starting a phone call. Never used as a face-to-face greeting.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: You passed the exam? Congratulations!
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 축하합니다 is the formal version. 축하하다 is the base verb meaning 'to congratulate.'

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Happy birthday! I prepared a gift.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: The Korean birthday song uses 생일 축하합니다 (formal). Koreans celebrate both solar and lunar birthdays.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example: 새해 복 많이 받으세요! 올해도 건강하세요.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Happy New Year! Stay healthy this year too.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Literally 'receive a lot of new year blessings.' Used for both solar (Jan 1) and lunar new year (설날).

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Wow, this looks delicious! Thank you for the food.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Said before eating to express gratitude to whoever prepared the meal. A key Korean table manner.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Thank you for the meal. It was really delicious.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Said after finishing a meal to show appreciation. Pair with 잘 먹겠습니다 before eating.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Welcome! How many people?
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: You'll hear this in every Korean shop and restaurant. Staff say it to greet customers entering.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: 성함 is the honorific word for name, used when asking elders.
Humble/polite form of 'I.' Always use 저 with people you don't know well or who are older.
Casual form of 'I.' Use only with close friends or people younger than you.
Asking age is normal in Korea because it determines the level of politeness you use.
Used with native Korean numbers. Korean age used to be 1-2 years older than international age, but Korea switched to international age in 2023.
어느 나라 means 'which country.' 나라 can also mean 'nation' in a broader sense.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example: 한국에 온 지 일 년 됐어요.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: It's been one year since I came to Korea.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Refers to South Korea. The full formal name is 대한민국. North Korea is 북한.
미국 사람 means 'American person.' Short for 미합중국 (美合衆國).
일본 사람 or 일본인 means 'Japanese person.' 일본어 means 'Japanese language.'

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: I can speak a little Chinese.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: 중국 사람 or 중국인 means 'Chinese person.' 중국어 means 'Chinese language.'
A common self-introduction topic. 무슨 일 하세요? is a softer way to ask what someone does.
대학생 is short for 대학교 학생 (university student). 중학생 and 고등학생 are middle/high school students.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: I'm an office worker. I work at an IT company.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Very common job title in Korea. 회사 means 'company' and 원 means 'person/member.'

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: Teacher, which school do you teach at?
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Also used as a respectful title for doctors, lawyers, and other professionals. Similar to 'Mr./Ms.' in formal situations.
전업 주부 means 'full-time homemaker.' The term is gender-neutral but traditionally associated with women.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: The doctor prescribed medicine for me.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Doctors are addressed as 의사 선생님 or just 선생님. 병원 means 'hospital.'

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: The nurse gave me a shot.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: 간호 means 'nursing/care' and 사 means 'person.' A respected profession in Korea.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: The chef at this restaurant is really famous.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: 요리 means 'cooking' and 사 means 'person.' 셰프 (from English 'chef') is also commonly used.
가 means 'song' and 수 means 'person/expert.' K-pop has made this a dream job for many young Koreans.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: I watched the drama that actor appeared in.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Used for both male and female actors. Korean dramas (한국 드라마/K-드라마) are popular worldwide.
One of the essential question words. 어디서 means 'from where' or 'at where' (어디 + 에서).
뭐 is the spoken/casual form of 무엇. In everyday speech, 뭐 is much more common.
누구 changes to 누가 when used as a subject (who did something). Example: 누가 했어요? (Who did it?)
Can sound confrontational if said with strong tone. Soften with 왜요? (why?) to sound more polite.
어떻게 지내세요? means 'How are you doing?' A very versatile question word.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Sino-Korean number. Used for dates, money, phone numbers, and math.
이월 = February (2nd month). Sino-Korean numbers are used for months.
분 (minutes) uses Sino-Korean numbers. 삼분 = three minutes.
사 can also mean 'death' (死) in Sino-Korean, so the number 4 is considered unlucky. Some buildings skip the 4th floor.
Money always uses Sino-Korean numbers. 오천 원 = 5,000 won.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: It rains a lot in June.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: When followed by certain sounds, 육 may be pronounced as '뉵' due to Korean pronunciation rules.
Sino-Korean numbers are used for math. 곱하기 means 'times/multiply.'
팔 also means 'arm.' Context makes the meaning clear. 8 is considered a lucky number.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: You need to memorize the multiplication table.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: 구구단 literally means '9×9 table' — the multiplication table that Korean kids memorize.
Sino-Korean numbers combine logically: 십일 = 11, 이십 = 20, 이십삼 = 23.
일백 is technically correct for 100 but Koreans just say 백. 이백 = 200, 삼백 = 300.
Like 백, you say 천 not 일천 for 1,000. 이천 = 2,000.
Korean counting groups by 10,000 (만) not 1,000. This is the trickiest part of Korean numbers for English speakers.
Shortens to 한 before counters: 한 개, 한 명, 한 잔. Native Korean numbers are used with counters.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Let's go together, just the two of us.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Shortens to 두 before counters: 두 개, 두 명. 둘이 means 'two people together.'
Shortens to 세 before counters: 세 개, 세 명. 셋 is used when counting standalone.
Shortens to 네 before counters: 네 개, 네 명. Since 네 sounds like 'your' (네), people often say 니 instead.
Does not shorten before counters. 다섯 개, 다섯 명.
Hours use native Korean numbers. 여섯 시 = 6 o'clock. Does not shorten.
Native Korean numbers are only commonly used up to 99. Beyond that, Sino-Korean numbers are standard.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: I go to work at eight o'clock.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Pronounced as '여덜' in casual speech. The ㅂ is sometimes silent.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: You have to come by nine o'clock.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: 까지 means 'by/until.' 아홉 시까지 = by 9 o'clock.
Combines with units: 열하나 = 11, 열둘 = 12. 열 번 = ten times.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: I'm twenty years old this year.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Shortens to 스무 before counters: 스무 살, 스무 개. This is an irregular form.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example: 서른 살이 되면 뭘 하고 싶어요?
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: What do you want to do when you turn thirty?
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Used mainly for age. For most other things above 20, Sino-Korean numbers are preferred.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: My father is forty-five years old.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Mostly used for counting age. In everyday life, Sino-Korean 사십 is more common for other contexts.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: My grandmother started exercising from age fifty.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Beyond 50, native Korean numbers become rare in daily use except for age.
The most common and versatile counter. When in doubt about which counter to use, 개 usually works.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: The four of us eat together.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Polite people counter. 분 is the honorific version: 두 분 (two people, respectful).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Do you want to drink a cup of coffee?
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: 한잔하다 colloquially means 'to have a drink (alcohol).' 커피 한 잔 = one cup of coffee.
Used for all animals regardless of size — from fish to elephants.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Please lend me a sheet of paper.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Used for paper, photos, tickets, and other flat objects. 사진 한 장 = one photo.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example: 이번 달에 책 세 권을 읽었어요.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: I read three books this month.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Specifically for bound volumes — books, notebooks, magazines.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: I bought a bottle of water.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: 병 also means 'illness/disease' as a separate word. Context makes it clear.
Used for cars, computers, phones, TVs, and other machines/devices.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: I bought a new set of clothes.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Counts outfits or sets. 한 벌 = one outfit/suit. Not used for individual items like socks.
Used with native Korean numbers: 한 살 (1 year old), 두 살 (2 years old). 몇 살 = how many years old.
한 번 = once, 두 번 = twice. Also used for bus/train route numbers: 버스 삼번 = bus number 3.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Get off at the third floor.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Uses Sino-Korean numbers: 일 층 (1st floor), 이 층 (2nd floor). 지하 일 층 = basement level 1.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: I have a ten-thousand won bill.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Always uses Sino-Korean numbers. Common bills: 천 원, 오천 원, 만 원, 오만 원.

가족 (Family).example_en: My family has four members.
가족 (Family).notes: 가족사진 means 'family photo.' Koreans often say 우리 가족 (our family) instead of '내 가족' (my family).

가족 (Family).example_en: My parents live in Busan.
가족 (Family).notes: 님 is an honorific suffix. 부모 alone is less respectful and rarely used in speech.

가족 (Family).example_en: Dad made dinner for us.
가족 (Family).notes: Casual/affectionate. 아버지 is the formal/respectful term for father. 아버님 is even more formal.

가족 (Family).example_en: Mom, what are you doing today?
가족 (Family).notes: Casual/affectionate. 어머니 is the formal/respectful term for mother. 어머님 is even more formal.

가족 (Family).example_en: My older brother goes to university.
가족 (Family).notes: Only used by males to address an older brother. Also used for older male friends by males.

가족 (Family).example_en: My older sister is good at cooking.
가족 (Family).notes: Only used by males to address an older sister. Also used for older female friends by males.

가족 (Family).example_en: Oppa, let's go watch a movie together.
가족 (Family).notes: Used by females for older brothers or older male friends. Also used as a term of endearment for boyfriends.

가족 (Family).example_en: My older sister bought me new clothes.
가족 (Family).notes: Used by females for older sisters or older female friends. A key relationship term in Korean culture.

가족 (Family).example_en: My younger brother is a high school student.
가족 (Family).notes: 남 means 'male' and 동생 means 'younger sibling.' Both males and females use this term.

가족 (Family).example_en: My younger sister is cute.
가족 (Family).notes: 여 means 'female' and 동생 means 'younger sibling.' Both males and females use this term.

가족 (Family).example_en: Grandfather told us a story.
가족 (Family).notes: Also used to address any elderly man politely, even strangers.

가족 (Family).example_en: I go to grandmother's house often.
가족 (Family).notes: Also used to address any elderly woman politely. 외할머니 is specifically maternal grandmother.

가족 (Family).example_en: My son starts elementary school this year.
가족 (Family).notes: 장남 means 'eldest son,' which holds special significance in traditional Korean families.

가족 (Family).example_en: My daughter sings really well.
가족 (Family).notes: 장녀 means 'eldest daughter.' Modern Korean families cherish sons and daughters equally.

가족 (Family).example_en: My husband cooks for me.
가족 (Family).notes: Formal word. In casual speech, 신랑 (groom) or the husband's name is sometimes used instead.

가족 (Family).example_en: I'm going on a trip with my wife.
가족 (Family).notes: Formal word. 부인 is another formal term. In casual speech, 와이프 (from English 'wife') is common.

가족 (Family).example_en: The child is playing in the park.
가족 (Family).notes: General word for child/kid. 아이들 means 'children' (plural). 어린이 is used in more official contexts.

가족 (Family).example_en: The baby is sleeping right now.
가족 (Family).notes: Used for infants and toddlers. 갓난아기 means 'newborn baby.'

가족 (Family).example_en: I bought a birthday present for my niece/nephew.
가족 (Family).notes: Covers both nieces and nephews. 조카딸 specifies niece; 조카아들 specifies nephew.

가족 (Family).example_en: My uncle lives in Seoul.
가족 (Family).notes: Specifically father's unmarried brother. 큰아버지 is father's older married brother. 작은아버지 is father's younger married brother.

가족 (Family).example: 이모가 맛있는 음식을 많이 해 주세요.
가족 (Family).example_en: My maternal aunt makes a lot of delicious food.
가족 (Family).notes: Specifically mother's sister. Also used casually for middle-aged women at restaurants, though some find it impolite.

가족 (Family).example_en: My paternal aunt lives in America.
가족 (Family).notes: Specifically father's sister. Korean has distinct terms for every family relationship based on which side.

가족 (Family).example_en: My cousin is getting married next week.
가족 (Family).notes: Covers all cousins. 사 means 'four' — a cousin is four family steps away (parent → grandparent → uncle/aunt → cousin).

가족 (Family).example_en: My mother-in-law made kimchi for us.
가족 (Family).notes: 시 prefix = husband's family. 시아버지 = husband's father. The in-law system has very specific terms in Korean.

가족 (Family).example_en: My mother-in-law (wife's mom) came to visit.
가족 (Family).notes: 장 prefix = wife's family. 장인어른 = wife's father. 님 is added for respect.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Have you eaten? (Did you eat rice?)
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 밥 먹었어요? is the most common Korean greeting — it shows you care about the person's well-being.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I eat bread in the morning.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Comes from Portuguese 'pão.' Korean bakeries (빵집) are very popular and creative.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Cold noodles are delicious in summer.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: General term for noodles. 잔치국수 (banquet noodles) is a classic Korean noodle dish.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: We grill the meat and eat it.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: General term for meat. Korean BBQ (고기집) is a central part of Korean dining culture.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Korean beef (hanwoo) is expensive.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 소 means 'cow.' 한우 (Korean beef) is considered premium and is much more expensive than imported beef.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Samgyeopsal is pork.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 돼지 means 'pig.' Pork is the most consumed meat in Korea.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: We make fried chicken with chicken meat.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 닭 means 'chicken (animal).' Note the ㄺ consonant cluster — pronounced as '닥'.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Do you like fish?
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 생선 is fish as food. 물고기 is fish as a living animal. Different words for different contexts.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Eating lots of vegetables is good for health.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 야채 is also used for vegetables but 채소 is considered more standard/proper.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I eat fruit after meals.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Korea has excellent seasonal fruits. Fruit is a common gift when visiting someone's home.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: One apple is 1,000 won.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 사과 also means 'apology' — a completely different word with the same pronunciation.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I eat a banana in the morning.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: A loanword from English. Korea imports most of its bananas from the Philippines.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: The strawberries are really sweet.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Korean strawberries are famous for being large and sweet. 딸기 season is winter to spring.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: We eat a lot of watermelon in summer.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 수 means 'water' and 박 means 'gourd.' A quintessential Korean summer fruit.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: The grapes look delicious.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Korean grapes (캠벨 포도) are often darker and more fragrant than Western varieties.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I can't eat a meal without kimchi.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Korea's most iconic food. Fermented vegetables (usually napa cabbage). There are over 200 varieties.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Please make soybean paste stew.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: A staple Korean comfort food. 찌개 means 'stew.' Served bubbling hot in a stone pot.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example: 소풍 갈 때 김밥을 싸 가요.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: We pack kimbap when we go on picnics.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 김 (seaweed) + 밥 (rice). Looks like sushi rolls but the flavor is distinctly Korean.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I put red pepper paste in bibimbap.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 비비다 means 'to mix' and 밥 means 'rice.' Mix everything together before eating.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Bulgogi is sweet and delicious.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 불 (fire) + 고기 (meat). Thin-sliced beef marinated in a sweet soy sauce mixture.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I bought tteokbokki in front of the school and ate it.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Korea's most popular street food. 떡 (rice cake) + 볶이 (stir-fried). Spicy, chewy, and addictive.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Let's go eat samgyeopsal for dinner tonight.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 삼 (three) + 겹 (layers) + 살 (meat). Grilled at the table and wrapped in lettuce with garlic and ssamjang.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Ramyeon comes to mind on rainy days.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Korean ramyeon is spicier than Japanese ramen. It's comfort food and a late-night staple.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I often eat cold noodles in summer.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 냉 means 'cold.' 물냉면 (in broth) and 비빔냉면 (spicy mixed) are the two main types.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: We marinate the ribs in sauce and grill them.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Can be beef (소갈비) or pork (돼지갈비). 양념갈비 is marinated; 생갈비 is plain.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Beer goes well with fried chicken.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Korean fried chicken is a cultural phenomenon. 치맥 = 치킨 + 맥주 (chicken and beer), a beloved combo.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: We make dumplings on Lunar New Year.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Can be steamed (찐만두), fried (군만두), or in soup (만두국). A holiday tradition.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: We eat rice cake on holidays.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Made from pounded rice. Hundreds of varieties. 떡국 (rice cake soup) is eaten on New Year's Day.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I fry an egg and eat it.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 계란 is another common word for egg. Both are widely used. 달걀 is considered pure Korean.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I like soft tofu stew.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: A staple in Korean cooking. 순두부 is soft/silken tofu. Used in stews, side dishes, and grilled.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I wash the rice and cook it.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 쌀 is raw rice grain; 밥 is cooked rice. Korean rice is short-grain and sticky.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Please put in just a little salt.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Essential seasoning. 소금 is also used in Korean superstitions to ward off bad luck.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Do you put sugar in your coffee?
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 설 means 'snow' reflecting sugar's white color. Korean cooking uses sugar in many savory dishes too.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I dip it in soy sauce and eat it.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: A foundational Korean seasoning. 국간장 (soup soy sauce) is lighter; 진간장 is darker and richer.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I put red pepper paste in bibimbap.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: One of Korea's essential condiments (장). Sweet, spicy, and fermented. Used in many Korean dishes.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I make stew with soybean paste.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Fermented soybean paste, one of Korea's 3 essential 장 (along with 고추장 and 간장). Rich umami flavor.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Adding sesame oil to namul makes it delicious.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 참 means 'true/real.' The nutty aroma of sesame oil is a signature of Korean cuisine.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Please give me a glass of water.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: In Korean restaurants, water is almost always free and self-serve. 냉수 means cold water.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I drink milk in the morning.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 우 means 'cow' and 유 means 'milk.' 바나나 우유 (banana milk) is a beloved Korean drink.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I'd like to drink orange juice.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Loanword from English 'juice.' Korea has many unique juice flavors like 한라봉 (Hallabong citrus).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example: 한국 사람들은 커피를 정말 많이 마셔요.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Korean people drink a lot of coffee.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Korea has one of the highest coffee consumption rates in the world. Cafes are everywhere.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I like green tea.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Includes all types: 녹차 (green tea), 보리차 (barley tea), 유자차 (citron tea). 보리차 is served free at many restaurants.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I want to have a glass of beer.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 맥 means 'barley.' Korean beer brands include Cass, Hite, and many craft breweries.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example: 소주는 한국에서 제일 인기 있는 술이에요.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Soju is the most popular alcohol in Korea.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Korea's national spirit. Clear, about 16-20% alcohol. Pour for others, never for yourself — it's etiquette.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Cola goes well with fried chicken.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Loanword from English. 사이다 in Korea refers to Sprite-like lemon-lime soda, not apple cider.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Let's go eat ice cream.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Loanword from English. Korea has unique flavors like 붕어빵 (fish-shaped pastry) and 인절미 (rice cake) ice cream.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: We eat cake on birthdays.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Korean cakes tend to be lighter and less sweet than Western cakes, often with fresh cream and fruit.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example: 과자를 너무 많이 먹으면 안 돼요.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: You shouldn't eat too many snacks.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: General term for packaged snacks and cookies. 새우깡 and 빼빼로 are iconic Korean snacks.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I boil potatoes and eat them.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 감자탕 (pork bone and potato stew) is a popular hearty Korean dish. 고구마 is sweet potato.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Please chop the carrot finely.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 당근 is also slang for '당연하지' (of course!). Used as internet slang: 당근이지!

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: When you cut onions, tears come out.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 양 means 'Western' — it literally means 'Western green onion.' 파 (green onion) is the Korean native variety.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Korean food uses a lot of garlic.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Korea is one of the world's top garlic consumers. Garlic is in almost every Korean dish.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: The chili pepper is too spicy!
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 고춧가루 (chili powder/flakes) is essential for making kimchi and many Korean dishes.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: We wrap samgyeopsal in lettuce and eat it.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 쌈 (wrapping food in leaves) is a key Korean eating style. Lettuce is the most common wrap.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I slice cucumbers thinly and make a salad.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 오이소박이 (stuffed cucumber kimchi) is a popular summer kimchi variety.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I eat tomatoes sprinkled with sugar.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: In Korea, tomatoes are often eaten as fruit with sugar rather than in savory dishes.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: We make kimchi with napa cabbage.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: The main ingredient in the most common type of kimchi (배추김치). 김장 is the annual kimchi-making tradition.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Adding mushrooms makes the broth delicious.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Common varieties: 표고버섯 (shiitake), 팽이버섯 (enoki), 느타리버섯 (oyster mushroom).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Korean chopsticks are metal.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Korean chopsticks are uniquely flat and metal (stainless steel), unlike wooden or bamboo ones in other countries.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: You eat soup with a spoon.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: In Korea, rice is eaten with a spoon (not chopsticks). 수저 means chopsticks + spoon set.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Is there a good restaurant near here?
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: General term for any eating establishment. More casual than 레스토랑.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: I'll take a look at the menu.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Loanword from English. Used interchangeably with 메뉴판 in casual speech.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Please give me the menu.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: 판 means 'board/plate.' This specifically refers to the physical menu you hold.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Please take our order.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Noun form. Used with 하다 to make the verb 주문하다 (to order).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: I'll order. One bibimbap, please.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: ~ㄹ게요 expresses the speaker's intention or promise. Very common when ordering.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Excuse me! Can we get more water, please?
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Literally means 'here.' Standard way to call a server in Korea. Raise your hand while saying it.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Excuse me, water please.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: 좀 softens the request and makes it more polite. Water is usually free at Korean restaurants.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example: 이거 주세요. 그리고 콜라도 하나 주세요.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: This, please. And one cola too, please.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Point at the menu while saying this. Very useful when you cannot read the menu.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example: 여기 뭐가 맛있어요? 처음 와 봤어요.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: What's good here? It's my first time visiting.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Great way to start a conversation with the server and get a recommendation.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: What's the recommended menu item?
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Use 추천하다 as a verb (to recommend). 추천해 주세요 = please recommend something.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example: 이거 매워요? 저는 매운 거 잘 못 먹어요.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Is this spicy? I can't handle spicy food well.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: From the adjective 맵다. Korea has many spicy dishes, so this question is very practical.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example: 덜 맵게 해 주세요. 아이가 먹을 거예요.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Please make it less spicy. A child will be eating it.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: 덜 means 'less.' You can also say 안 맵게 해 주세요 (make it not spicy).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Please eat a lot! (Enjoy your meal!)
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: 많이 드세요 is a common polite phrase said when serving food. 드시다 is the honorific of 먹다.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example: 조금만 주세요. 배가 별로 안 고파요.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Just give me a little. I'm not that hungry.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: 조금만 adds 만 (only) to emphasize 'just a little.' Often shortened to 좀 in casual speech.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Please give me more rice.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: In many Korean restaurants, rice and side dishes (반찬) refills are free. Just ask!

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Can I get it to go?
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Literally means 'packaging.' 포장 돼요? is the quickest way to ask about takeout.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Please pack up the leftovers.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Koreans commonly take home leftovers. This phrase works for both ordering takeout and packing leftovers.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: The check, please.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: In Korea you usually pay at the counter near the exit, not at the table.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Can I see the bill?
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: 서 is a suffix meaning 'document.' 계산서 is the itemized bill.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: I'll pay by card.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Card payment is extremely common in Korea. Almost everywhere accepts cards.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: I'll pay in cash.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: 현금 is less common now but some small street food stalls only take cash.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: I need a receipt.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Different from 계산서. 영수증 is the proof-of-payment receipt you get after paying.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: This kimchi stew is really delicious!
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: 맛 (taste) + 있다 (to exist) = tasty. One of the most useful words in Korea.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: The food here is a bit not tasty.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: 맛 + 없다 (to not exist). Be careful using this directly to someone who cooked for you!

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: This is too spicy! Water, please.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Irregular conjugation: 맵다 → 매워요. The ㅂ changes to 워 in conjugation.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: This dessert is really sweet.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Conjugates as 달아요. Korean desserts like 호떡 and 붕어빵 are popular sweet snacks.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example: 국이 좀 짜요. 물 좀 넣어 주세요.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: The soup is a bit salty. Please add some water.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Conjugates regularly: 짜요. Also means 'stingy' in slang.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: This coffee is a bit bitter.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: 쓰다 has multiple meanings: bitter, to write, to use. Context tells you which one.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example: 이 김치 좀 셔요. 오래된 거예요?
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: This kimchi is a bit sour. Is it old?
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Well-fermented 김치 is supposed to be sour. 신 김치 (sour kimchi) is great for 김치찌개.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: I ate too much so I'm stuffed.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: 배 (stomach) + 부르다 (to be full). Irregular: 배부르다 → 배불러요.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I don't have time. I need to go quickly.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Means both 'time' (general) and 'hour' (duration). 두 시간 = two hours.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: It's three o'clock now.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Use native Korean numbers for hours: 한 시, 두 시, 세 시, etc.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: Please wait just ten minutes.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Use Sino-Korean numbers for minutes: 십 분, 이십 분, 삼십 분, etc.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: Please wait just thirty seconds.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Uses Sino-Korean numbers like 분. Not as commonly used in daily conversation.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I have class at 9 AM.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: 오 (午, noon) + 전 (前, before) = before noon. Used in formal time expressions.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: Let's meet at 2 PM.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: 오 (午, noon) + 후 (後, after) = after noon. Paired with 오전.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: What do you do in the morning?
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Also means 'breakfast' (아침 식사 or just 아침). 아침 먹었어요? = Did you eat breakfast?

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: Do you want to eat lunch together?
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Also means the lunch meal itself. 점심시간 = lunch time (usually 12-1 PM in Korea).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: Do you have time in the evening?
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Also means 'dinner.' 저녁 먹었어요? is a common greeting meaning 'Have you eaten dinner?'

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: Don't walk around alone at night.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Korea is generally safe at night, but this is still common advice. 밤새 = all night long.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: Waking up at dawn is hard.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Roughly 1 AM to sunrise. 새벽 배송 (dawn delivery) is a popular service in Korea.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: The weather is nice today.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: One of the most frequently used time words. 오늘부터 = starting from today.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: What are you going to do tomorrow?
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: 내일 봐요 (see you tomorrow) is a very common farewell.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: What did you do yesterday?
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Always used with past tense. 어제 저녁에 = yesterday evening.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I have an exam the day after tomorrow.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Korean has a single word for this unlike English. Very commonly used.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I met a friend the day before yesterday.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Also written as 그제. Less common than 모레 but still widely used.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: Are you busy now?
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Very high-frequency word. 지금 당장 = right now, immediately.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I'll call you later.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: 나중에 봐요 = see you later. Can be vague about exactly when.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I have to wake up early tomorrow.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Adverb form. Opposite of 늦게. 일찍 자요 = go to sleep early.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I went to sleep late yesterday.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Adverb form of 늦다. 늦었어요 = I'm late (as in arriving late).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I always eat breakfast.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Synonymous with 언제나. Both are commonly used in everyday speech.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: What time do you usually wake up?
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Also means 'ordinary/normal.' 보통 사람 = ordinary person.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I sometimes watch Korean movies.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Frequency is lower than 보통 but higher than 거의 안 (almost never).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I have a meeting on Monday.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: 월 = moon/month. The days use: 월(moon), 화(fire), 수(water), 목(wood), 금(gold), 토(earth), 일(sun).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I have Korean class on Tuesday.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: 화 = fire (火). 화요일마다 = every Tuesday.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I'm a bit busy on Wednesday.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: 수 = water (水). Wednesday is the middle of the work week.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: Do you have time on Thursday?
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: 목 = wood/tree (木). 목요일까지 = by/until Thursday.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: It's Friday so I'm in a good mood!
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: 금 = gold (金). 불금 (불타는 금요일) = 'burning Friday,' slang for TGIF.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: What are you going to do on Saturday?
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: 토 = earth (土). Part of the weekend (주말).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I usually rest on Sundays.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: 일 = sun (日). Many shops and restaurants are still open on Sundays in Korea.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: Let's meet this Friday.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: 이번 = this time/current. Works with other time words: 이번 달 (this month), 이번 해 (this year).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I'm going on a trip next week.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: 다음 = next. Also: 다음 달 (next month), 다음에 (next time).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I caught a cold last week.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: 지난 = last/past. Written as one word (지난주) unlike 이번 주 and 다음 주.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I exercise every day.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: 매 = every. Same pattern: 매주 (every week), 매달 (every month), 매년 (every year).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I play soccer every Saturday.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: Can be combined with days: 매주 월요일 = every Monday.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I started learning Korean this year.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: 올 is a prefix meaning 'this (current).' Only used with 해 (year).

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I went to Korea last year.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: 작 (昨) = previous. 작년 is more common than 지난해 in speech.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: I want to go to Korea next year.
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: 내 (來) = coming. 내년 봄에 = next spring.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: When is your birthday?
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: 생일 축하해요 = Happy birthday. Koreans celebrate with 미역국 (seaweed soup) on birthdays.

시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).example_en: What did you do on the weekend?
시간 & 요일 (Time & Days).notes: 주 (week) + 말 (end). One of the most common small-talk topics in Korean.

장소 (Places).example_en: I want to go home.
장소 (Places).notes: 에 marks destination. 집에서 (at home) vs 집에 (to home). Very important distinction.

장소 (Places).example_en: How do you get to school?
장소 (Places).notes: 학 (學, study) + 교 (校, school). Elementary = 초등학교, middle = 중학교, high = 고등학교.

장소 (Places).example_en: I work at a company.
장소 (Places).notes: 회사원 = office worker/company employee. 회사에 다니다 = to work at a company.

장소 (Places).example_en: What floor is the office on?
장소 (Places).notes: 사무 (business/work) + 실 (room). Refers to the physical office space.

장소 (Places).example_en: I'm sick so I need to go to the hospital.
장소 (Places).notes: In Korea, you go to 병원 even for minor things like a cold. It covers clinics too.

장소 (Places).example_en: I bought medicine at the pharmacy.
장소 (Places).notes: 약 (medicine) + 국 (bureau). Look for the green cross sign. Open late in many areas.

장소 (Places).example_en: I bought fruit at the mart.
장소 (Places).notes: Short for 슈퍼마켓. Big chains include 이마트, 홈플러스, 롯데마트.

장소 (Places).example_en: I'll go buy water at the convenience store.
장소 (Places).notes: 편의 = convenience. Korea has tons of these (CU, GS25, 세븐일레븐). Open 24 hours.

장소 (Places).example_en: I need to go to the bank and send money.
장소 (Places).notes: 은 (銀, silver) + 행 (行, business). Major banks: 국민, 신한, 우리, 하나.

장소 (Places).example_en: I sent a package at the post office.
장소 (Places).notes: 우체 (postal) + 국 (bureau). Less used now due to online services, but still common for packages.

장소 (Places).example_en: How long does it take to get to the airport?
장소 (Places).notes: 공 (air) + 항 (port). 인천공항 (Incheon Airport) is Korea's main international airport.

장소 (Places).example_en: Let's meet at Seoul Station.
장소 (Places).notes: Used for train and subway stations. Attach the station name before 역: 강남역, 홍대역.

장소 (Places).example_en: Where is the bus stop?
장소 (Places).notes: 정류장 = stopping place. Can also just say 버스 정거장. Look for numbered bus stops.

장소 (Places).example_en: I like studying at cafes.
장소 (Places).notes: Korea has a massive cafe culture. 카페 is everywhere and many people study or work there.

장소 (Places).example_en: Have you been to that restaurant? They say it's good.
장소 (Places).notes: 식 (食, eat) + 당 (堂, hall). General term for any Korean eatery.

장소 (Places).example_en: I take walks in the park.
장소 (Places).notes: 공 (public) + 원 (garden). 한강공원 (Han River Park) is a famous spot in Seoul.

장소 (Places).example_en: I borrowed a book from the library.
장소 (Places).notes: 도서 (books) + 관 (building). 빌리다 = to borrow. Many Koreans study at the library.

장소 (Places).example_en: I saw a new movie at the theater.
장소 (Places).notes: 영화 (movie) + 관 (hall). Major chains: CGV, 메가박스, 롯데시네마.

장소 (Places).example_en: I bought a gift at the department store.
장소 (Places).notes: 백화 (百貨, hundred goods) + 점 (store). More upscale than 마트. Famous: 롯데, 현대, 신세계.

장소 (Places).example_en: I ate tteokbokki at the market.
장소 (Places).notes: Traditional markets like 남대문시장 and 광장시장 are great for street food and bargains.

장소 (Places).example_en: I went to the shopping mall on the weekend.
장소 (Places).notes: Loanword. Large malls like 코엑스몰 and 스타필드 are popular in Korea.

장소 (Places).example_en: Where is the restroom?
장소 (Places).notes: 화장 (makeup) + 실 (room). This is the polite way to say it. Public restrooms are usually clean and free.

장소 (Places).example_en: I go to church every Sunday.
장소 (Places).notes: 교 (teaching) + 회 (gathering). Christianity is one of the major religions in Korea.

장소 (Places).example_en: I visited a temple on the weekend.
장소 (Places).notes: Buddhist temple. Famous ones include 불국사, 해인사. 사 (寺) is another word for temple.

장소 (Places).example_en: Did you book a hotel?
장소 (Places).notes: Loanword from English. Budget alternatives in Korea: 모텔, 게스트하우스, 한옥 스테이.

장소 (Places).example_en: I live in an apartment.
장소 (Places).notes: Most Koreans live in apartments. 아파트 complexes are the dominant housing type.

장소 (Places).example_en: How many rooms are there?
장소 (Places).notes: Also used in compounds: 노래방 (karaoke room), PC방 (internet cafe), 찜질방 (spa).

장소 (Places).example_en: I'm cooking in the kitchen.
장소 (Places).notes: Also called 주방 (more formal). Korean kitchens often have floor heating like the rest of the home.

장소 (Places).example_en: I watch TV in the living room.
장소 (Places).notes: 거 (居, reside) + 실 (room). The main shared space in a Korean home.

장소 (Places).example_en: The bathroom is clean.
장소 (Places).notes: 욕 (bath) + 실 (room). Refers to the actual bathing room. 화장실 is more common in public.

장소 (Places).example_en: I attend a cram school.
장소 (Places).notes: Private tutoring academies. Extremely common in Korea. 영어 학원 = English academy.

장소 (Places).example_en: I majored in economics at university.
장소 (Places).notes: 대학 or 대학교 both work. Shortened to 대 in casual speech: 어느 대 나왔어요?

장소 (Places).example_en: My child goes to kindergarten.
장소 (Places).notes: 유치 (infant) + 원 (garden). For ages 3-5 typically.

장소 (Places).example_en: The kids are playing at the playground.
장소 (Places).notes: 놀이 (play) + 터 (place/ground). Found in most 아파트 complexes.

장소 (Places).example_en: I go to the gym every day.
장소 (Places).notes: 체육 (physical education) + 관 (hall). Also called 헬스장 (health club) colloquially.

장소 (Places).example_en: I go to the swimming pool often in summer.
장소 (Places).notes: 수영 (swimming) + 장 (place). Many 아파트 complexes have their own pools.

장소 (Places).example_en: I got a haircut at the hair salon.
장소 (Places).notes: 미용 (beauty) + 실 (room). 남자 haircut places are sometimes called 이발소.

장소 (Places).example_en: I left my coat at the dry cleaner.
장소 (Places).notes: 세탁 (laundry) + 소 (place). Mostly used for dry cleaning in Korea.

장소 (Places).example_en: I need to get gas at the gas station.
장소 (Places).notes: 주유 (refueling) + 소 (place). 셀프 주유소 = self-service gas station.

장소 (Places).example_en: I lost my wallet so I went to the police station.
장소 (Places).notes: 경찰 (police) + 서 (office). Emergency number in Korea is 112 for police.

장소 (Places).example_en: The fire station is near my house.
장소 (Places).notes: 소방 (fire-fighting) + 서 (office). Emergency number is 119 for fire and ambulance.

장소 (Places).example_en: I lost my passport so I need to go to the embassy.
장소 (Places).notes: 대사 (ambassador) + 관 (building). Most embassies in Seoul are in the 용산 area.

장소 (Places).example_en: I want to go to the beach in summer.
장소 (Places).notes: 해 (sea) + 변 (side). Famous beaches: 해운대 (Busan), 경포대 (Gangneung).

장소 (Places).example_en: I went to the mountain on the weekend.
장소 (Places).notes: Hiking (등산) is Korea's national hobby. Mountains are everywhere and well-maintained.

장소 (Places).example_en: I like eating chicken by the Han River.
장소 (Places).notes: 한강 (Han River) is the iconic river through Seoul. 치맥 (chicken + beer) by the river is a must.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: There's a bank on the left.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 왼 = left + 쪽 = side/direction. 왼손 = left hand.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Go to the right.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 오른 = right + 쪽 = side/direction. 오른손 = right hand.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Let's meet in front of the school.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: Used with 에 or 에서. 앞으로 = forward/from now on.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: There's a parking lot behind the building.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 뒤에 = behind (location). 뒤로 = backward (direction).

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: There's a book on top of the desk.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 위에 = on top of / above. One of the essential location particles.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: There's a bag under the chair.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 아래에 = below/under. Sometimes shortened to 밑에 which is very similar.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: There's a cafe next to the post office.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 옆에 = next to. 바로 옆에 = right next to.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: It's between the bank and the pharmacy.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: A 와/과 B 사이에 = between A and B. Also used for relationships: 사이가 좋다 = get along well.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Please go inside the building.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 안에 = inside. Opposite of 밖에. 안에서 = from inside.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: It's raining outside.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 밖에 = outside. 밖에서 = from outside. 밖으로 나가다 = to go outside.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Can I sit here?
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: Part of the 이/그/저 system: 여기 (here, near me), 거기 (there, near you), 저기 (over there).

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Please wait there.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: Refers to a place near the listener or a previously mentioned place.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: What's that building you can see over there?
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: Refers to a place far from both speaker and listener. Often accompanied by pointing.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Please come this way.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 이 (this) + 쪽 (direction/side). Very commonly used when guiding someone.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: If you go that way, there's a station.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 그 (that) + 쪽 (direction). Also a polite way to say 'you' in formal contexts.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: The restroom is over that way.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 저 (that far) + 쪽 (direction). Used when pointing to somewhere distant.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: It's close from here.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: Adverb form. Adjective: 가깝다 (close). Irregular: 가깝다 → 가까워요.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: My home is far from the office.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: Adverb form. Adjective: 멀다 (far). Irregular: 멀다 → 멀어요.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: There's a mart across from the bank.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 건너 (to cross) + 편 (side). Same meaning as 맞은편.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: There's a cafe on the opposite side of the station.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 맞은 (facing) + 편 (side). Interchangeable with 건너편 in most cases.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Go straight on this road.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 직 (straight) + 진 (advance). Often used in GPS navigation and giving directions.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Go right at the intersection.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: ~(으)로 가세요 is the standard pattern for giving directions. 가세요 is polite imperative.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Go left at the convenience store.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: Same pattern as 오른쪽으로 가세요. Use landmarks as reference points.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Where is the restroom?
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: Essential question pattern. 어디 = where. Attach the subject with 이/가 before 어디.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Can I go this way?
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: Also means 'way/path' figuratively. 길을 잃다 = to get lost.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Please show me the map.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 지 (land) + 도 (diagram). Most Koreans use 네이버 지도 or 카카오맵 on their phones.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: If you turn the corner, there's a cafe.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 모퉁이를 돌다 = to turn a corner. 코너 (loanword) is also used.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Go left at the intersection.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 사 (four) + 거리 (street) = four-way intersection. 삼거리 = three-way intersection.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Cross at the crosswalk.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 횡단 (crossing) + 보도 (walkway). In casual speech, people sometimes say 건널목.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Come out through exit 3.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 출 (out) + 구 (opening). Subway stations have numbered exits. Great for giving meeting locations.

쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: General word for any small shop. More casual than 상점 (商店).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: There are a lot of items.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Refers to physical goods/merchandise. Different from 것 which is more abstract.
~(으)러 가다 means 'to go in order to.' 사다 → 사요 (present), 샀어요 (past).
팔다 → 팔아요. ㄹ irregular: ㄹ drops before ㄴ, ㅂ, ㅅ endings.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: The price is a bit expensive.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 가 (price) + 격 (level). More formal than just asking 얼마예요?
The most essential shopping phrase. Works everywhere from markets to department stores.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: It's too expensive. Please give me a discount.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 비싸다 → 비싸요. Bargaining is common at traditional markets but not at fixed-price stores.
싸다 → 싸요. 싸게 사다 = to buy cheaply. Can also mean 'to wrap.'
할인하다 = to discount. 할인 카드 = discount card. 할인 행사 = discount event/sale.
Loanword from English. Used interchangeably with 할인 in casual speech.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: I'd like to exchange the size.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: General word for 'to change/exchange.' 바꾸다 → 바꿔요. Also means 'to switch.'
환 (return) + 불 (pay). 환불받다 = to receive a refund. Keep your receipt for refunds.
교 (exchange) + 환 (swap). More formal than 바꾸다. Used for store exchanges.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Do you have a different size?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Loanword. Korean sizes may differ from Western sizes. 프리사이즈 = free size (one size fits all).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example: 이거 좀 커요. 작은 거 있어요?
쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: This is a bit big. Do you have a small one?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 크다 → 커요. Used for both size and scale. 큰 = big (adjective before nouns).
작다 → 작아요. 작은 사이즈 = small size.
Also shortened to 색. 무슨 색깔 좋아해요? = What color do you like?

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Please give me the red one.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 빨간 (red) + 색 (color). The adjective alone is 빨갛다 (to be red).
파란 (blue) + 색 (color). The adjective is 파랗다 (to be blue).
검은 (black) + 색. Also called 까만색 (pure/deep black) in casual speech.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: The white one looks the cleanest.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 하얀 (white) + 색. Also 흰색. 하얗다 is the base adjective (to be white).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: I'll pay by card. Here you go.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: ~(으)로 할게요 = I'll do it by/with. Very common at checkout counters.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: I'll pay cash. Do you have change?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 거스름돈 = change (money returned). Some places give a small discount for cash.
Plastic bags cost money in Korea (usually 50-100 won). Bring your own bag to save.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Receipt, please. I need to submit it to my company.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Some stores ask 영수증 필요하세요? (Do you need a receipt?) at checkout.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Can I try on this dress?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: ~아/어 봐도 돼요? = may I try ~ing? 입다 = to wear (clothes). 신다 = to wear (shoes).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Excuse me, how much is this?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Point at the item while asking. In markets, items may not have price tags.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example: 좀 깎아 주세요. 두 개 살게요.
쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Please give a discount. I'll buy two.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 깎다 = to cut/shave off. Only use at traditional markets, not at chain stores.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example: 마음에 안 들어요. 다른 거 있어요?
쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: I don't like it. Do you have something else?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 다른 = different/other. 마음에 들다 = to like (literally: to enter one's heart).
Remove shoes when entering Korean homes, some restaurants, and temples.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: There are a lot of pretty clothes.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: General term for clothing. 옷가게 = clothing store. 옷을 입다 = to wear clothes.
Covers all types: 청바지 (jeans), 반바지 (shorts). Always plural in meaning.
미니 치마 = mini skirt. 긴 치마 = long skirt. 짧다 = to be short.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: You look cooler when you wear a hat.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 모자를 쓰다 = to wear a hat. 쓰다 is the verb used for hats and glasses.
General term for any bag: backpack, purse, briefcase. 책가방 = school bag.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The weather is really nice today.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 날씨 is used in everyday conversation; 기후 means 'climate' for long-term patterns.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: It's too hot in summer.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 덥다 is for weather/temperature. For hot food or drinks, use 뜨겁다.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: It's really cold outside today.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 춥다 is for weather/body feeling. For cold objects or drinks, use 차갑다.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: When spring comes, the weather is warm.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: Can describe weather, clothing, personality, or food temperature.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The breeze is refreshing.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 시원하다 can mean 'cool' for weather or 'refreshing' for cold drinks and breezes.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: It's raining a lot, so I need an umbrella.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 비 is the noun 'rain.' To say 'it rains,' use 비가 오다 (rain comes).

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: It will rain tomorrow.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: Korean literally says 'rain comes' rather than 'it rains.' The subject marker 가 attaches to 비.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The first snow has fallen!
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 눈 means both 'snow' and 'eye.' Context makes the meaning clear. 첫눈 = first snow of the season.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: It snows a lot in winter.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: Same pattern as 비가 오다. You can also say 눈이 내리다 (snow falls), which sounds more literary.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The wind is blowing hard today.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 바람 also means 'wish/hope' or 'affair' in different contexts. Here it means wind.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: A cool breeze is blowing on the mountain.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 불다 means 'to blow.' It is also used for blowing out candles (촛불을 불다).

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The sky is clear so I feel good.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 맑다 describes a clear sky or clear water. For sunny weather, 맑은 날씨 is common.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The sky is cloudy today.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 흐리다 can also mean 'blurry' or 'dim' when talking about vision or images.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: There are many clouds so the sun isn't visible.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 구름이 끼다 means 'clouds gather/it gets cloudy.'

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: There was a lot of fog this morning.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 안개가 끼다 means 'fog sets in.' Driving in fog: 안개 속에서 운전하다.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: A typhoon is coming, so we need to be careful.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: Korea experiences typhoons mainly in late summer and early fall. 태 comes from 한자 太 (great).

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: I didn't bring an umbrella so I got rained on.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 비를 맞다 literally means 'to get hit by rain.' 접이식 우산 = folding umbrella.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: During the rainy season, it rains every day.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 장마철 is the rainy season period, usually late June to mid-July in Korea.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: In spring, many flowers bloom.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 봄 is March to May in Korea. 벚꽃 (cherry blossoms) are a famous spring symbol.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: I want to go to the sea in summer.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: Korean summer is hot and humid, especially during 장마 (monsoon). June to August.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: In autumn, the fall foliage is really beautiful.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 단풍 means 'autumn leaves / fall colors.' 가을 is September to November.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: In winter, you have to wear warm clothes.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: Korean winters are very cold and dry. December to February.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: Today the temperature is 30 degrees.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: Korea uses Celsius (섭씨). 영하 means below zero: 영하 5도 = minus 5 degrees.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: It's too humid in summer.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 습도 means 'humidity.' Korea's summer humidity can feel oppressive.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: In winter, the air is dry.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 건조하다 is used for weather, skin, or food. 피부가 건조하다 = skin is dry.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The fine dust is bad, so I wear a mask.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: A major concern in Korea, especially in spring. Check 미세먼지 forecasts on weather apps.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The weather forecast said it will be clear tomorrow.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 일기 here means 'weather' (not 'diary,' which is the same word). 예보 = forecast.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: When the sun rises, the weather gets warm.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 해 also means 'year.' 해가 뜨다 = sun rises, 해가 지다 = sun sets.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The moon is really bright tonight.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 달 also means 'month.' 보름달 = full moon, 반달 = half moon.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: You can see many stars in the countryside.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 별 can also mean 'star' as in celebrity (별 같은 사람). 별똥별 = shooting star.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: My head hurt so I took medicine.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 머리 means both 'head' and 'hair.' 머리를 감다 = to wash one's hair.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I wash my face in the morning.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 얼굴이 작다 (small face) is a compliment in Korea.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: My eyes are tired so I want to rest a bit.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Same spelling as 'snow.' 눈물 = tears (eye + water). 눈이 크다 = to have big eyes (a compliment).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I caught a cold and my nose is stuffed.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 코를 풀다 = to blow one's nose. 코피 = nosebleed.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: Please open your mouth wide.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 입맛 = appetite. 입이 짧다 = to be a picky eater (mouth is short).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example: 음악을 너무 크게 들으면 귀가 아파요.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: If you listen to music too loud, your ears hurt.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 귀걸이 = earring. 귀가 밝다 = to have sharp hearing.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I brush my teeth three times a day.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 이 is casual, 치아 is more formal/medical. 이를 닦다 = to brush teeth. 사랑니 = wisdom tooth.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: My throat hurts so I can't talk.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 목이 마르다 = to be thirsty (throat is dry). 목도리 = scarf.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: If you use the computer for a long time, your shoulders hurt.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 어깨가 뻣뻣하다 = shoulders are stiff. Office workers often complain about 어깨 통증 (shoulder pain).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I exercised a lot so my arms hurt.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 팔꿈치 = elbow. 팔짱을 끼다 = to fold one's arms.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I wash my hands before eating.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 손님 = guest (hand + person). 손잡이 = handle.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I cut my finger while cooking.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 엄지손가락 = thumb, 검지 = index finger, 약지 = ring finger, 새끼손가락 = pinky.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: When I exercise, my chest pounds.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 가슴이 아프다 can mean physical chest pain or emotional heartache.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I'm hungry. Let's go eat!
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 배 also means 'boat/ship' and 'pear.' 배가 고프다 = to be hungry, 배가 부르다 = to be full.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: If you sit for a long time, your back hurts.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 등 also means 'etc.' in writing. 등산 = mountain climbing (climbing one's back).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I hurt my lower back lifting something heavy.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 허리 통증 (lower back pain) is extremely common. 허리띠 = belt.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I walked a lot so my legs hurt.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 다리 also means 'bridge.' 다리를 꼬다 = to cross one's legs.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: The new shoes are small so my feet hurt.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 발가락 = toe. 발목 = ankle. Koreans remove shoes indoors.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I fell and hurt my knee.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 무릎을 꿇다 = to kneel. Knee pain is common among hikers (등산하는 사람).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).english: to hurt; to be sick/in pain
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: Where does it hurt?
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Very versatile: 배가 아프다 (stomach hurts), 마음이 아프다 (heart aches). 아파요 is the 해요체 form.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I caught a cold so I'm resting at home.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 감기에 걸리다 = to catch a cold. 독감 = influenza (more severe).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I had a fever so I couldn't go to school.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 열이 나다 = to have a fever. 체온 = body temperature. 38도 이상 = over 38 degrees (fever).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: My cough won't stop.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 기침을 하다 = to cough. 기침약 = cough medicine.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: My headache was bad so I took medicine.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 두 = head (한자 頭), 통 = pain (한자 痛). 두통약 = headache medicine.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I ate spoiled food and got a stomachache.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 배탈이 나다 = to get a stomachache. 체하다 = to have indigestion.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: Please take the medicine after eating.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 약을 먹다 = to take medicine (literally 'eat'). 약을 바르다 = to apply medicine (ointment).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I bought cold medicine at the pharmacy.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: In Korea, pharmacies are everywhere. You can get many medicines without a prescription.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I was sick so I went to the hospital.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Koreans say 병원 for any clinic or hospital. 대학병원 = university hospital (large hospital).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: The doctor prescribed medicine for me.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 의사 선생님 is the polite way to address a doctor. 의사 alone is used when referring to the profession.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: The nurse gave me a shot.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 간호 = nursing/care. 간호사 is gender-neutral in Korean.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I'm relieved the surgery went well.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 수술을 받다 = to have/undergo surgery. 수술실 = operating room.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I'm scared of shots.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 주사를 맞다 = to get a shot. 주사를 놓다 = to give a shot. 예방주사 = vaccine shot.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I'm going to the hospital for a health checkup.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 건강검진 = health checkup (formal). 혈액 검사 = blood test. 검사 also means 'prosecutor' in legal context.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I have a cat allergy.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Loanword from English 'allergy.' 꽃가루 알레르기 = pollen allergy.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I exercise every day for my health.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 운동 = exercise/sport (noun). 헬스장 = gym. 운동을 하다 and 운동하다 are both correct.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: Our grandmother is very healthy.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 건강 = health (noun). 건강하게 지내세요 = Stay healthy (common farewell).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I worked a lot today so I'm tired.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 피곤 = fatigue (noun). 너무 피곤해요 is one of the most common Korean complaints.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I couldn't sleep last night.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 잠을 자다 = to sleep, 잠이 오다 = to feel sleepy, 잠이 안 오다 = can't fall asleep.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I usually sleep at 11 PM.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 낮잠을 자다 = to take a nap. 주무시다 is the honorific form (for elders).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).english: to wake up; to get up
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I wake up at 7 in the morning.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 일어나다 also means 'to stand up' or 'to happen/occur.' 일어나세요! = Wake up! / Stand up!

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I take the bus to school every day.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 시내버스 = city bus, 고속버스 = express bus, 마을버스 = village/local bus.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: In Seoul, the subway is the most convenient.
교통 (Transportation).notes: Seoul's subway system is excellent. Lines are numbered and color-coded. Also called 전철.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I was late so I took a taxi.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 모범택시 = deluxe taxi (black, more expensive). 콜택시 = call taxi (reserved by phone/app).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: It takes two hours to arrive by airplane.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 비행 = flight. 비행기를 타다 = to take a plane. 비행기표 = plane ticket.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I want to go to Busan by train.
교통 (Transportation).notes: KTX is Korea's high-speed train. 기차역 = train station. 무궁화호 = regular train.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I went to Jeju Island by boat.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 배 has multiple meanings: boat, stomach, pear. 여객선 = passenger ship, 유람선 = cruise ship.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I ride a bicycle in the park.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 따릉이 is Seoul's public bike-sharing system. 자전거 도로 = bike lane.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I want to buy a new car.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 자동차 is formal; 차 is casual and much more common in conversation. 차 also means 'tea.'

교통 (Transportation).example_en: There are really many delivery motorcycles.
교통 (Transportation).notes: Loanword from English 'auto-bike.' Very common for 배달 (delivery) in Korea.

교통 (Transportation).example: 여기서 몇 번 버스를 타야 해요?
교통 (Transportation).example_en: What number bus should I take here?
교통 (Transportation).notes: 타다 is used for all vehicles. It also means 'to burn' in a different context.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I get off at the next stop.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 내리다 also means 'to come down' (rain, snow). 비가 내리다 = rain falls.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Transfer from Line 2 to Line 3.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 갈다 (to change) + 타다 (to ride). 환승 is the formal noun for 'transfer.'

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I booked the ticket in advance.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 승차권 is more formal for transport tickets. 표를 끊다 = to buy a ticket (older expression).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: How much is the bus fare?
교통 (Transportation).notes: 기본요금 = base fare. 추가요금 = additional charge.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I need to charge money on my transit card.
교통 (Transportation).notes: T-money is the most common transit card brand in Korea. 충전하다 = to recharge.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Drive carefully!
교통 (Transportation).notes: 운전면허 = driver's license. 운전면허증 = physical license card.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I like driving.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 음주운전 = drunk driving (very serious in Korea). 초보운전 = beginner driver.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Can I park here?
교통 (Transportation).notes: 주차금지 = no parking. 주차비 = parking fee.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: The parking lot is full.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 지하주차장 = underground parking. 주차장 is often abbreviated as P on signs.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: What time do you arrive at the airport?
교통 (Transportation).notes: 도착 = arrival (noun). Opposite of 출발하다 (to depart).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: The airplane departs at 3 PM.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 출발 = departure (noun). 출발 시간 = departure time.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Please come out through Exit 3.
교통 (Transportation).notes: Subway exits are numbered. Giving directions with exit numbers is very common in Korea.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Where is the entrance?
교통 (Transportation).notes: 입 = enter, 구 = opening. Opposite of 출구 (exit). 정문 = main entrance/gate.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I'll get off at the next stop.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 버스 정류장 = bus stop. For subway, use 역 (station) instead.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Let's meet at Seoul Station.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 역 is specifically for rail stations. 지하철역 = subway station, 기차역 = train station.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: How long does it take to get to Incheon Airport?
교통 (Transportation).notes: 인천국제공항 = Incheon International Airport, Korea's main international airport. 김포공항 = domestic flights.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Did you check the bus schedule?
교통 (Transportation).notes: 시간 = time, 표 = table/chart. 수업 시간표 = class schedule.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Just go straight along this road.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 길을 잃다 = to get lost. 길을 묻다 = to ask for directions. Very common word.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Traffic in Seoul is complicated.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 교통체증 = traffic jam. 대중교통 = public transportation.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: If the traffic light is red, you have to stop.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 신호 = signal, 등 = light. 초록불 = green light, 빨간불 = red light.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: What is your hobby?
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: One of the most common self-introduction questions in Korean. 취미 생활 = hobby life/leisure activities.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: Do you want to go see a movie this weekend?
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 영화관 = movie theater. 영화를 보다 = to watch a movie. Korean cinema is world-renowned.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I like listening to music.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 음악을 듣다 = to listen to music. K-pop = 케이팝. 클래식 음악 = classical music.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: This song is really good!
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 노래를 부르다 = to sing a song. 노래방 = karaoke room.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I want to learn to dance.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 춤 = dance (noun). 춤을 추다 is the separated form. K-pop 댄스 is very popular.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: What kind of exercise/sport do you like?
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 운동 covers both exercise and sports. 운동선수 = athlete. 운동화 = sneakers.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I play soccer with friends.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 축구를 하다 = to play soccer. Korea's national team is very popular. 월드컵 = World Cup.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: Shall we go watch a baseball game?
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 야구 is extremely popular in Korea. 프로야구 = professional baseball. 야구장 = baseball stadium.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I often play basketball at school.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 농구를 하다 = to play basketball. 농구 코트 = basketball court.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I go to the sea to swim in summer.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 수영장 = swimming pool. 수영을 하다 = to swim. 수영복 = swimsuit.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I run every morning.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 달리다 = to run (verb). 마라톤 = marathon. 조깅 = jogging.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I'm going hiking this weekend.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 등산 is a hugely popular hobby in Korea. 등산복 = hiking clothes. 등산화 = hiking boots.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I do yoga to relieve stress.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 요가 학원 = yoga studio/class. 명상 = meditation, often paired with yoga.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I'm going on a trip to Japan next month.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 여행을 가다 = to go on a trip. 해외여행 = overseas travel. 국내여행 = domestic travel.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: Could you take a photo for me?
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 사진을 찍다 = to take a photo. 셀카 = selfie (from 'self camera').

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I want to learn Korean cooking.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 요리하다 = to cook. 요리사 = chef. 집에서 요리해 먹다 = to cook and eat at home.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: My younger sibling draws well.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 그림을 그리다 = to draw a picture. 그림책 = picture book.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I play online games with friends.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: PC방 = internet/gaming cafe. Korea has a major esports (e스포츠) culture.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I take a walk in the park in the evening.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 산책하다 = to take a walk. 산책을 하다 also works. 반려동물과 산책 = walking with a pet.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: Reading is the best hobby.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 독서하다 = to read (books). More formal than 책을 읽다 (to read a book).

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I went shopping in Myeongdong.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 온라인 쇼핑 = online shopping. 쇼핑몰 = shopping mall. 쿠팡 = Korea's major e-commerce site.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: My father likes fishing.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 낚시를 하다 = to go fishing. 낚싯대 = fishing rod. 바다낚시 = sea fishing.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I'm going camping this weekend.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 캠핑장 = campsite/campground. 글램핑 = glamping (glamorous camping), very popular in Korea.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: After the work dinner, we go to karaoke.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 노래 = song + 방 = room. A quintessential Korean social activity. 코인노래방 = coin karaoke (cheaper, by song).

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: Are there any interesting dramas these days?
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 한국 드라마 = Korean drama (K-drama). 넷플릭스 = Netflix. 드라마를 보다 = to watch a drama.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I watch TV in the evening.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: In conversation, Koreans usually say TV (티비). 텔레비전 is the full word but rarely used in casual speech.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: The internet in Korea is really fast.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Korea has some of the fastest internet in the world. 와이파이 = Wi-Fi.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: What is your cell phone number?
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Also called 휴대폰 (more formal) or 스마트폰 (smartphone). 핸드폰 is most common in casual speech.
