취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: This book is really interesting.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 책을 읽다 = to read a book. 책방/서점 = bookstore. 도서관 = library.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: My father reads the newspaper every morning.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 신문을 읽다 = to read a newspaper. 뉴스 = news. Print newspapers are declining in Korea too.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I'm going to a concert next week!
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: K-pop 콘서트 tickets are very hard to get. 공연 is the native Korean word for 'performance.'

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I'm going to see a musical performance.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 공연장 = performance venue. Covers theater, musicals, concerts, and other live shows.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: Let's go to the art exhibition together.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 전시 = exhibition/display. 전시회를 보다 / 전시를 보다 = to see an exhibition.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: Have you been to the National Museum?
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 국립중앙박물관 = National Museum of Korea (in Seoul). 박물관 입장료 = museum admission fee.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: This art gallery has many famous paintings.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 미술 = art/fine arts. 미술관 vs 갤러리 - both are used. 현대미술관 = contemporary art museum.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I learned piano when I was young.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 피아노를 치다 = to play piano (치다 = to hit/strike). 피아노 학원 = piano academy.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I'm learning to play guitar.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 기타를 치다 = to play guitar. Note: 기타 also means 'other/etc.' in different contexts.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I always sing when I shower.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 노래를 부르다 is more common than 노래하다 in natural speech. Both are correct.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I like drawing landscapes.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 그림을 그리다 = to draw a picture. 그리다 also means 'to miss someone' (그리워하다).

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I take lots of photos when I travel.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 사진을 찍다 = to take a photo. 찍다 also means 'to stamp' or 'to dip (in sauce).'

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm really happy because I passed the exam.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: 기쁘다 is for a specific reason or event. Conjugates irregularly: 기쁘 → 기뻐요 (ㅡ drops).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm happy when I'm with my family.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: 행복하다 is a deeper, more lasting happiness than 기쁘다. From 한자 幸福.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: This movie is so sad.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: ㅡ irregular: 슬프 → 슬퍼요. Often used with 너무 for emphasis.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example: 친구가 약속을 안 지켜서 화가 나요.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm angry because my friend didn't keep the promise.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: 화가 나다 (with subject marker 가) is the full form. 화내다 means 'to get angry at someone.'

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: It's scary to walk alone at night.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: ㅂ irregular: 무섭 → 무서워요. Can mean 'I'm scared' or 'it's scary' depending on context.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I was surprised because there was a sudden loud sound.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Past tense 놀랐어요 is very common. 깜짝 놀라다 means 'to be startled.'

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I sometimes feel lonely because I live alone.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: ㅂ irregular: 외롭 → 외로워요. 외로움 is the noun form meaning 'loneliness.'

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm bored because I have nothing to do.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Very casual/everyday word. 지루하다 is a more formal way to say 'boring.'

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm worried because I have an interview tomorrow.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: 걱정하다 = to worry (active); 걱정되다 = to be worried (passive/involuntary feeling).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I always get nervous before presentations.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: 긴장하다 = to be tense (active); 긴장되다 = to feel nervous (involuntary). From 한자 緊張.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I feel embarrassed singing in front of people.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: ㅂ irregular: 부끄럽 → 부끄러워요. Can mean both 'shy' and 'embarrassed.'

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm proud because my son studies hard.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: ㅂ irregular: 자랑스럽 → 자랑스러워요. 자랑하다 means 'to brag/boast.'

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I was touched after hearing that story.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: 감동받다 (to receive being moved) is also very common. From 한자 感動.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I was a bit disappointed after seeing the results.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: From 한자 失望. Often softened with 좀 (a bit) in conversation.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm tired because I worked a lot today.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: From 한자 疲困. Very high-frequency word in daily life.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm hungry because I didn't eat breakfast.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: ㅡ irregular: 배고프 → 배고파요. Literally 'stomach is empty.' 배 = stomach.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm full because I ate too much.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: ㅡ irregular: 배부르 → 배불러요. Opposite of 배고프다.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm thirsty after exercising.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: ㅡ irregular: 목마르 → 목말라요. Literally 'throat is dry.' 목 = throat/neck.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm sleepy because I couldn't sleep last night.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: 졸리다 = to feel sleepy; 졸다 = to doze off. Don't confuse the two.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I have a headache. (My head hurts.)
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: ㅡ irregular: 아프 → 아파요. Used for all kinds of pain: 배가 아프다, 다리가 아프다, etc.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: The weather is nice today.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: 좋다 = something is good; 좋아하다 = to like (active verb). Both are essential.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I dislike spicy food.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: 싫다 = to dislike (adjective); 싫어하다 = to dislike (active verb). Opposite of 좋다.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: This drama is really fun/interesting.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Literally 'interest exists.' 재미 = fun/interest + 있다 = to exist.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: That movie was boring.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Literally 'interest doesn't exist.' 재미 + 없다. Opposite of 재미있다.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm excited because I'm going on a trip tomorrow!
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Casual and energetic feeling. 신나는 음악 = exciting/upbeat music.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm frustrated because we can't communicate.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Can mean physically stuffy (in a room) or emotionally frustrated. Very common in Korean.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: This sofa is really comfortable.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Used for both physical comfort and feeling at ease. 편안하다 is a more formal synonym.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: This chair is very uncomfortable.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: 불 (不) + 편하다. Used for physical discomfort or inconvenient situations.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm satisfied with this result.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: From 한자 滿足. Opposite: 불만족하다 (dissatisfied).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example: 그때 더 열심히 공부할 걸 후회해요.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I regret not studying harder back then.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: From 한자 後悔. Often used with -(으)ㄹ 걸 (I should have...).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I miss my hometown.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: ㅂ irregular: 그립 → 그리워요. Used for people, places, or times you long for.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm upset because my friend said something mean to me.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: 속 = inside/heart + 상하다 = to go bad. Literally 'the inside is hurt.'

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I feel wronged because I got scolded even though I didn't do it.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: A uniquely Korean emotion — feeling unfairly blamed or treated. No perfect English equivalent.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm excited because it's my first date.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: A fluttery, anticipatory excitement, often romantic. 설렘 is the noun form.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I feel proud and fulfilled after finishing the project.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: A warm sense of accomplishment. More personal than 자랑스럽다 which can be about others.

색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).notes: ㅎ irregular: 빨갛 → 빨개요. 빨간 is the modifier form (빨간 모자 = red hat).

색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).example_en: The sky is really blue today.
색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).notes: ㅎ irregular: 파랗 → 파래요. 파란 is the modifier form (파란 바다 = blue sea).

색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).example_en: The leaves turn yellow in autumn.
색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).notes: ㅎ irregular: 노랗 → 노래요. 노란 is the modifier form (노란 꽃 = yellow flower).

색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).example_en: It snowed so the world is white.
색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).notes: ㅎ irregular: 하얗 → 하얘요. 하얀 is the modifier form (하얀 구름 = white cloud).
ㅎ irregular: 까맣 → 까매요. 까만 is the modifier form (까만 고양이 = black cat).
초록색 is a noun (color name). 초록색의 or 초록 is used as a modifier. No ㅎ irregular form.
주황색 is a noun. Also called 오렌지색 in casual speech.
보라색 is a noun. 보랏빛 means 'purple light/hue' and sounds more poetic.
분홍색 is a noun. Also called 핑크색 casually. 분홍 can be used alone as modifier.
From 한자 灰色. 회색빛 means 'grayish hue.'
From 한자 褐色. Sometimes 브라운 (from English 'brown') is used for fashion.
큰 is the modifier form (큰 집 = big house). Opposite: 작다.

색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).example_en: These clothes are too small for me.
색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).notes: 작은 is the modifier form (작은 강아지 = small puppy). Opposite: 크다.
많은 is the modifier form. 많이 is the adverb form (많이 먹어요 = eat a lot).
적은 is the modifier form. Opposite: 많다. Don't confuse with 적다 (to write down).
긴 is the modifier form (긴 머리 = long hair). Opposite: 짧다.
짧은 is the modifier form. Used for length, not height. Opposite: 길다.
넓은 is the modifier form (넓은 공원 = spacious park). Opposite: 좁다.
좁은 is the modifier form. Opposite: 넓다.
높은 is the modifier form. Used for buildings, mountains, prices — not for people's height (키가 크다).

색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).example_en: This table is a bit low.
색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).notes: 낮은 is the modifier form. Opposite: 높다. Don't confuse with 낮 (daytime, noun).
ㅂ irregular: 무겁 → 무거워요. Opposite: 가볍다.
ㅂ irregular: 가볍 → 가벼워요. Opposite: 무겁다.
ㅡ irregular: 빠르 → 빨라요. Adverb: 빨리. Opposite: 느리다.
느린 is the modifier form. Adverb: 느리게. Opposite: 빠르다.
ㅂ irregular: 새롭 → 새로워요. 새 is a shorter modifier (새 차 = new car).
오래된 is the modifier form. Only for things, not people. For people's age, use 나이가 많다.
좋은 is the modifier form (좋은 사람 = good person). One of the most used adjectives.
ㅡ irregular: 나쁘 → 나빠요. 나쁜 is the modifier form. Opposite: 좋다.
ㅡ irregular: 예쁘 → 예뻐요. Mostly used for women, children, or things. 아름답다 is more literary.
Past tense form 잘생겼어요 is the standard way to say it. Literally 'well-formed.'
ㅂ irregular: 귀엽 → 귀여워요. Used for babies, animals, small things, and idols.
깨끗한 is the modifier form. 깨끗하게 is the adverb form. Opposite: 더럽다.

색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).example_en: Your hands are dirty. Wash them.
색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).notes: ㅂ irregular: 더럽 → 더러워요. Opposite: 깨끗하다.
밝은 is the modifier form (밝은 미래 = bright future). Opposite: 어둡다.
ㅂ irregular: 어둡 → 어두워요. Opposite: 밝다.
따뜻한 is the modifier form (따뜻한 차 = warm tea). Between 뜨겁다 and 차갑다.
ㅂ irregular: 차갑 → 차가워요. For touch/objects. For weather, use 춥다.
ㅂ irregular: 뜨겁 → 뜨거워요. For touch/objects. For weather, use 덥다.
ㅂ irregular: 부드럽 → 부드러워요. Used for texture, personality, and voice.
Onomatopoeic origin. Also used figuratively: 딱딱한 분위기 = stiff atmosphere.
ㅂ irregular: 쉽 → 쉬워요. 쉬운 is the modifier form. Opposite: 어렵다.
ㅂ irregular: 어렵 → 어려워요. Opposite: 쉽다.
From 한자 重要. 중요한 is the modifier form (중요한 약속 = important appointment).

색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).example_en: That road is dangerous at night.
색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).notes: From 한자 危險. 위험한 is the modifier form. Opposite: 안전하다 (safe).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: The most versatile verb in Korean. Combines with many nouns to form compound verbs: 공부하다, 운동하다, etc.
Takes the particle 에 for destination. Irregular in some forms: 가 + 아요 → 가요 (not 가아요).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: My friend comes to my house.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Irregular: 오 + 아요 → 와요. Opposite of 가다.
밥 먹었어요? (Have you eaten rice?) is a common Korean greeting meaning 'How are you?'

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I drink a lot of water.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 시 + 어요 → 셔요. Used for all drinks: 커피를 마시다, 술을 마시다.
잘 자요 = Good night (literally 'sleep well'). Very common expression.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).english: to wake up, to get up
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I wake up at 7 every morning.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Also means 'to stand up' or 'to happen/occur.' Context determines the meaning.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I wash my hands before eating.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 씻 has a double consonant batch (ㅆ). 샤워하다 is used for 'to shower.'

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: What are you going to wear today?
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Only for clothes on the body. Shoes = 신다, hat = 쓰다, glasses = 쓰다.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I take off my shoes when I enter the house.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Used for removing clothes, shoes, hats, glasses. Opposite of 입다/신다/쓰다.
Only for footwear (shoes, socks, slippers). 신발 (shoes) comes from this verb.
앉으세요 = Please sit down (polite). The ㄵ consonant cluster simplifies in pronunciation.
일어서다 = to stand up (from sitting). 멈춰 서다 = to stop and stand.
ㄷ irregular: 걷 → 걸어요. Don't confuse with 걷다 (to collect/gather) which is regular.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: The children are running in the playground.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Can mean both 'run' and 'jump.' 달리다 specifically means 'to run.'

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).english: to see, to watch, to look
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 보 + 아요 → 봐요. Very versatile: 시험을 보다 = take a test, TV를 보다 = watch TV.
ㄷ irregular: 듣 → 들어요. 수업을 듣다 = to take a class.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).english: to speak, to say, to tell
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 말씀하시다 is the honorific form. 이야기하다 is 'to talk/chat.'

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I'm reading an interesting book these days.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: The ㄺ consonant cluster: pronounced [익] before consonants, [일] before vowels.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I write in my diary every day.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Multiple meanings: write, use, wear (hat/glasses), bitter. Context is key. ㅡ irregular: 쓰 → 써요.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I make a cake on weekends.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: ㄹ verb: the ㄹ drops before ㄴ, ㅂ, ㅅ. 만든 = that was made (modifier).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I buy fruit at the market.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 사 + 아요 → 사요. 사 주다 = to buy for someone.
ㄹ verb. Opposite: 사다. 팔리다 = to be sold (passive).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I give a present to my friend.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 주 + 어요 → 줘요. -아/어 주다 as auxiliary means 'do for someone.'
Opposite: 주다. 받아들이다 = to accept.
ㄹ verb. Opposite: 닫다. 열리다 = to be opened (passive).
Opposite: 열다. 닫히다 = to be closed (passive).
Used for lights, electronics, heaters. Opposite: 끄다.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I turn off the light before sleeping.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: ㅡ irregular: 끄 → 꺼요. Opposite: 켜다. Also means 'to extinguish.'
Two meanings: 'to look for' (searching) and 'to find' (success). Also: 'to withdraw money.'

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Please wait here for a moment.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Often used with -아/어 주세요 for polite requests. 기다림 = the wait (noun).
만나서 반갑습니다 = Nice to meet you (formal). 만남 = meeting/encounter (noun).
전화 = telephone. 전화를 받다 = to answer the phone. 전화를 끊다 = to hang up.
공부 (noun) + 하다. From 한자 工夫. The most common word for academic study.
일 (noun: work) + 하다. 직장에 다니다 = to go to work (attend a workplace).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).english: to rest, to take a break
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I rest at home on weekends.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Also means 'to breathe' in compound 숨을 쉬다. 휴식 is the formal noun for 'rest.'
시작 (noun) + 하다. From 한자 始作. Can be transitive or intransitive.
끝나다 = it ends (intransitive). 끝내다 = to finish it (transitive). 끝 = end (noun).
From 한자 到着. Takes 에 particle for the destination.
From 한자 出發. Opposite: 도착하다. 출발 시간 = departure time.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Let's hang out together on the weekend.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: ㄹ verb. For adults, it means 'to hang out/have fun,' not just children's play.
Active verb (takes 을/를). 좋다 (adjective) vs 좋아하다 (verb): 커피가 좋아요 vs 커피를 좋아해요.
Active verb (takes 을/를). Stronger than 안 좋아하다. Opposite: 좋아하다.
From 한자 必要. The needed thing takes 이/가 (subject marker), not 을/를.
ㄹ verb. 알겠습니다 = I understand/got it. Opposite: 모르다.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I don't know much about that.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: ㅡ irregular: 모르 → 몰라요. Opposite: 알다. 모르겠어요 = I'm not sure.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).english: to exist, to have, to be (at a place)
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: One of the most important Korean words. Location + 에 있다. Opposite: 없다.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).english: to not exist, to not have
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Opposite: 있다. 재미없다, 맛없다 show how 없다 combines with nouns.
ㄹ verb. 살 + ㅂ니다 → 삽니다. Takes 에서 for the place where you live.
배우 + 어요 → 배워요. Don't confuse with 배우 (actor/actress, noun).
가르치 + 어요 → 가르쳐요. Takes 에게/한테 for the person taught.
돕다 (to help) + 주다 (to give). 도와주세요 is the most common way to ask for help.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I borrow books from the library.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Means both 'borrow' and 'lend' — context determines which. 빌려주다 = to lend.
잃다 (to lose) + 버리다 (completely). 버리다 adds a sense of 'completely gone.'

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I cry when I watch sad movies.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: ㄹ verb. 울음 = crying (noun). 울리다 = to make someone cry.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I laughed because that story was funny.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Covers both laughing and smiling. 미소 짓다 specifically means 'to smile.'

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I clean my room every weekend.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 청소 (noun: cleaning) + 하다. From 한자 清掃. 대청소 = deep cleaning.
빨래 (noun: laundry) + 하다. 빨래를 널다 = to hang laundry. 빨래를 개다 = to fold laundry.
요리 (noun: cooking/dish) + 하다. From 한자 料理. 요리사 = chef.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I drive to work every day.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 운전 (noun: driving) + 하다. From 한자 運轉. 운전면허 = driver's license.
Used for all transportation: 버스를 타다, 택시를 타다, 비행기를 타다. Opposite: 내리다.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).english: to get off, to go down
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I get off at the next station.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Opposite of 타다 for transportation. Also means 'to fall' (비가 내리다 = rain falls).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: It takes 30 minutes from home to school.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: For time: 시간이 걸리다. For illness: 감기에 걸리다 = to catch a cold.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I changed to a new phone.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Active verb (you change something). 바뀌다 = to be changed (passive/intransitive).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).english: to fix, to repair, to correct
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Used for repairing things and correcting mistakes. 고장나다 = to break down.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: The weather is very nice today.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Neutral/standard 'very.' Can be used in both spoken and written Korean.
More formal than 아주. Common in news, reports, and formal writing.
Polite but natural in conversation. 정말요? = Really? (with surprise).
More casual than 정말. Also used as a noun meaning 'the real thing.' 진짜? = For real?
Short for 조금. Also softens requests: 좀 비켜 주세요 sounds gentler than without 좀.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: Please give me just a little water.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: More formal/full form of 좀. 조금씩 = little by little.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: Please eat a lot. (Enjoy your meal.)
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Adverb form of 많다. 많이 드세요 is a common polite phrase when serving food.
Adverb form of 빠르다. 빨리빨리 (hurry hurry) is a famous Korean cultural concept.
Essential phrase for language learners. Opposite: 빨리.
Opposite: 못. 잘 먹겠습니다 = I will eat well (said before meals). 잘 지내요? = How are you?
Placed before the verb. 못하다 = to be bad at. 못 vs 안: 못 = can't, 안 = don't/won't.
Placed before the verb for negation. For 하다 verbs: 공부 안 해요 (not 안 공부해요).
또 can link items: 사과, 또 바나나 = apples, and also bananas.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: Please say it one more time.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: 다시 implies repeating. 또 implies something additional or recurring. Subtle difference.
Neutral 'already.' States a fact without surprise. Compare with 벌써.
아직 + positive = still. 아직 + negative = not yet. 아직도 adds emphasis.
Unlike 이미, 벌써 carries surprise or disbelief that something happened so soon.
From 한자 恒常. 언제나 is a native Korean synonym.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: I come to this restaurant often.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Between 항상 (always) and 가끔 (sometimes) in frequency.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: What time do you usually wake up?
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Also an adjective meaning 'ordinary/average.' 보통이 아니다 = not ordinary (exceptional).
Less frequent than 자주. 가끔씩 is a slightly emphasized form.
절대(로) + negative verb = never. From 한자 絶對. 절대로 is the full adverb form.
Always used with negative verbs. From 한자 全. Adds strong emphasis to negation.
거의 다 = almost all/everything. 거의 안 = hardly/barely.
Often paired with -(으)ㄹ 거예요 (future guess). Less certain than 확실히 (certainly).

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: You must come! / Make sure to come!
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Used for emphasis in requests and promises. 꼭 해야 돼요 = You definitely have to do it.
먼저 가세요 = Please go first (polite). Also means 'before (someone else).'
나중 = later time (noun). Opposite: 먼저. 나중에 봐요 = See you later.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: Do you want to eat lunch together?
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: 같이 is casual/spoken; 함께 is more formal/written. Both are very common.
혼자서 adds emphasis. 혼자 살다 = to live alone. Opposite: 같이/함께.
Multiple uses: 바로 여기 = right here; 바로 그거예요 = That's exactly it.
Very common in storytelling. 갑작스럽다 is the adjective form (sudden).
Implies waiting/anticipation. Positive nuance: something long-awaited happened.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: I drank coffee, and then took a walk.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Connects sentences. For connecting nouns, use 하고 or (이)랑 instead.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: It rained. So I took an umbrella.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Shows cause → result. Connects two sentences where the first is the reason.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: I want to go. But I don't have time.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Shortened to 근데 in casual speech. Can also change topics (by the way).

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example: 어렵지만 재미있어요. 하지만 시간이 더 필요해요.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: It's difficult but fun. However, I need more time.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: More formal/written than 그런데. Purely contrasting (doesn't change topic).

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).english: then, if so, in that case
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example: 배고프다고요? 그러면 같이 밥 먹으러 가요.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: You're hungry? Then let's go eat together.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Shortened to 그럼 in casual speech. Responds to a condition or statement.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: It's hard. But still, I won't give up.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Acknowledges a difficulty but continues anyway. Very common in daily speech.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: I couldn't go. Because I was sick.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Gives a reason for the previous statement. Often paired with -거든요 at the end of the explanation.
